conclusion: To determine when particles A and B meet, we need to find the time at which their positions are the same. The position of each particle can be found by integrating the velocity-time graph.
The velocity-time graph for particle A is a triangle for the first 2t0 seconds, indicating constant acceleration.
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the position as a function of time.
The area under the triangle for the first 2t0 seconds is calculated as 1/2 * 2v0 * 2t0 = 2v0t0.
The position of A as a function of time for 0 ≤ t ≤ 2t0 is sA(t) = v0t.
For 2t0 < t ≤ 3t0, the velocity of particle A is decreasing linearly from 2v0 to v0.
The area under this segment is a trapezoid calculated as 1/2 * (2v0 + v0) * t0 = 3/2 v0t0.
The position of A as a function of time for 2t0 < t ≤ 3t0 is sA(t) = 5/2 v0t0 + 3/2 v0t.
For 3t0 < t ≤ 6t0, the velocity of particle A is decreasing linearly from v0 to 0.
The area under this segment is a triangle calculated as 1/2 * v0 * 3t0 = 3/2 v0t0.
The position of A as a function of time for 3t0 < t ≤ 6t0 is sA(t) = 2v0t - v0t0.
The velocity-time graph for particle B is a straight line with a slope of 1/5.
The area under the velocity-time graph for particle B gives the position as a function of time.
The area under the line for 0 ≤ t ≤ 6t0 is a triangle calculated as 1/2 * v0 * 6t0 = 3v0t0.
The position of B as a function of time is sB(t) = 3v0t0.
To find when A and B meet, we need to solve for t when sA(t) = sB(t).
For 0 ≤ t ≤ 2t0, solving v0t = 3v0t0 gives t = 3t0, which is not possible since t ≤ 2t0.
